stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on a factory level, a remake of a stage from his previous project 'Only Body May'. The stream focused on implementing visual effects like electrical sparkles, fixing bugs related to player-triggered effects and camera behavior, importing new assets from artist Biobak, and discussing future level concepts.

development_findings.summary: The project's next major levels are planned to be a 'Space Casino' (Crystal 14) and a 'Paper Craft level' (Crystal 15).
The team is forced to work around certain unfixable graphical bugs inherent to the GlideN64 plugin, which impacts the final visuals.
development_findings.quote: This is unfortunately going to be bugged forever. This is a Glideon bug. Nothing we can do.

development_findings.summary: Kaze debugged a complex issue with particles not following a path by tracing it to a simple mathematical error in his code where he had forgotten a square root function.
A design decision was made to make falling into oil less punishing; instead of instant death, the player will just respawn with reduced health.
development_findings.quote: I don't want that to be that punishing for no reason, you know. You can just respawn with less health.

development_findings.summary: A red coin challenge will reward the player with a radar after collecting a few coins, serving as a player-friendly guidance mechanic.
development_findings.quote: I think collecting three to get a radar is like a fun way of doing it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a fixed camera for an elevator section, troubleshooting bugs related to player jumping and collision to prevent the player from getting stuck.
Touching a 'Fuzzy' enemy triggers a dizzying, VHS-rewind-style visual and audio effect, which Kaze was particularly proud of.
development_findings.quote: How fucking cool is that effect, dude?

development_findings.summary: Kaze is systematically working through a to-do list for the current level, with plans to finish the factory area over the weekend and return to the 'ice castle' level next.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes strongly in maintaining player agency, expressing intense dislike for games like Super Mario Sunshine that frequently interrupt gameplay with non-interactive cutscenes.
context_findings.quote: Every single time the game takes control away from me, it just feels like a small kick to my balls.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels that collectibles and objectives should have meaningful progress tied to them, otherwise they can detract from the fun by creating dead ends.
context_findings.quote: If you find out that they don't actually count towards anything, doesn't that kind of reduce how much fun you're having?

context_findings.summary: Kaze has come to accept that unoptimized code is a common reality in development, reserving his frustration for external factors like dealing with German bureaucracy from abroad.
context_findings.quote: I have accepted that most code is written pretty unoptimized. I just turn into a sad cat when I have to deal with German bureaucracy.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses exhaustion after working on the game even before the stream began, indicating long work hours on the project.
Kaze mentions a personal aversion to spending money, in the context of buying new clothes.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided real-time feedback in chat, pointing out that Kaze was using an incorrect or placeholder fan model, which led to Kaze implementing the correct asset live on stream.
Biobak created the remade assets for the factory level and still has more to contribute to it.
Biobak assisted Kaze with a technical issue in Blender 4.0, explaining how to use the color picker to find a specific vertex color needed to fix a visual bug.
Biobak gave creative feedback on the sparkle effect Kaze was implementing, critiquing its appearance.
biobak.quote: These are star sparkles, not electrical sparkles.

zeina.summary: Kaze is waiting for Bowser's chair animations, which are being created by Zeina.

key_stories.title: Debugging the Electrical Sparkles
key_stories.summary: While programming a sparkle effect, Kaze spent time debugging why the particles were not following their intended path. The complex-looking problem was ultimately solved by a simple math correction, highlighting a common reality of programming.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed to create a visual effect of sparkles moving along electrical wires but they were appearing in the wrong location.
key_stories.process: Kaze used debug Mario models to visualize the sparkle positions. Seeing they were misplaced, he analyzed his positioning and movement code, eventually identifying a simple but critical math error.
key_stories.outcome: After realizing he omitted a square root function in his distance calculation, Kaze fixed the code and the sparkles behaved as intended. He then fine-tuned their speed and size.
key_stories.key_quote: I forgot the SQR, okay now it works. I'm not even gonna test if it works, I just know it works.

key_stories.title: The Unrecognized Fan Asset
key_stories.summary: Kaze showcased a fan asset he was unhappy with, only for the artist, Biobak, to point out in chat that it was the wrong model. This led to a live asset swap, demonstrating the team's direct and efficient collaborative workflow.
key_stories.challenge: While showing off a spinning fan, Kaze noted it looked visually inconsistent with the rest of the level's lighting.
key_stories.process: Kaze displayed the fan asset in-game. Biobak, the artist, immediately identified it in the stream chat as an incorrect or old version. This prompted Kaze to find and import the correct asset live.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze imported the correct, higher-quality fan models from Biobak, which integrated seamlessly into the level and looked much better.
key_stories.key_quote: That is not my fan. Patronity test has come out. It is in fact not your fan.

open_questions.context: Kaze is remaking a level from his previous project, 'Only Body May,' and is importing new assets for it from Biobak.
questions: What was the motivation to revisit and remake a level from a previous project instead of creating something entirely new?
How do you decide what elements to keep versus what to enhance or discard when remaking your own work?
Biobak, what is your artistic approach when remaking a level? Are you trying to faithfully upscale the original vision or create a completely new interpretation?

open_questions.context: Kaze points out a graphical glitch with some lights and states it's an unfixable bug in the GlideN64 plugin.
questions: You mentioned a graphics bug was 'bugged forever'. How do permanent, unfixable technical limitations like that influence your design choices?
Do you have to design around these known issues from the start, or do they force you to compromise on a creative vision later on?
What's the emotional reaction to hitting a wall like that? Is it frustrating, or just an accepted part of the challenge of N64 development?

open_questions.context: Kaze briefly mentioned he is waiting on 'Bowser's chair animations' which are being made by Zeina.
questions: Zeina, can you walk us through your process for creating an animation for an N64 character like Bowser?
What's the technical pipeline for your animations? How do you and Kaze collaborate to get your work into the game and functioning correctly?
What are the unique challenges or constraints you face when animating for the N64 compared to modern platforms?

open_questions.context: Kaze revealed that two future levels are planned: a 'Space Casino' and a 'Paper Craft level'.
questions: Where did the ideas for a Space Casino and a Paper Craft level come from?
How far along are those concepts? Are they just titles, or do you have core gameplay mechanics or visual ideas already planned?

open_questions.context: Kaze went on a passionate rant about his hatred for Super Mario Sunshine, specifically citing its frequent cutscenes that interrupt gameplay.
questions: You feel very strongly about games taking control away from the player. Can you elaborate on why maintaining that constant player agency is a core principle for you?
